repnme.cdata!: Malawi - Third Social Action Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Social Action Fund
            Project in Malawi were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: 1) improved accountability system for
            community development is critical in order to enhance
            positive perceptions among beneficiaries, and other
            stakeholders including donors. This provides an incentive
            for their support and involvement. For this to be achieved
            there is need to strengthen the information, education and
            communication (IEC) so as to enhance civic engagement and
            community accountability. 2) The first adaptable program
            loan (APL 1) has managed to put in place proper
            accountability systems; through the APL 1, several
            innovations were made with regard to results monitoring and
            measurement. Such systems need to be maintained at each
            level of project implementation. For example, at the
            community level, there is need to promote the use of
            community monitoring and feedback through the community
            statistics days as an integral part of the monitoring and
            evaluation framework. At the local authority (LA) and
            program level, there is need to promote participatory
            development of delivery benchmarks related to the community
            sub-project cycle so that beneficiaries and stakeholders are
            aware of what they have to be accountable; and 3) the
            sustainable mechanisms to secure continuity and
            functionality of community assets and institutions
            established through the APL 1 and other similar
            interventions are important achievements for this project,
            and need to be institutionalized.

10271788.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!: Malawi - Third Social Action Fund Project (APL)

abstracts.cdata!:
Under The Third Social Action Fund
            Project (APL) (MASAF 3) for Malawi, the distributed nodes of
            social capital generated through MASAF I and I1 will be
            networked to both optimize the social capital generated as
            well as to facilitate i t s incremental conversion into
            economic capital. There are five project components. The
            first component, Community Development Projects combines two
            of the current components under MASAF 11, Community
            Sub-projects and Public Works Program, for effective
            integration into the local authority (LA)  management
            framework. It will continue to finance demand-driven
            community-based socio-economic activities, including
            infrastructure, which include inter alias: construction
            and/or rehabilitation related to the provision of basic
            social services in health, education and water;
            afforestation, terracing, community roads and bridges,
            community centers, food processing technologies, energy
            efficiency interventions, training, and others. The Social
            Support Projects stimulates and supports traditional coping
            systems which rely on the extended family to mitigate
            against foster households experiencing deepening poverty
            after taking in vulnerable individuals. The vulnerable
            include: widows and widowers, the aged, orphans and foster
            parents, the destitute, the disabled, persons affected by
            HIVIAIDS, and malnourished under-fives. The project will
            finance initiatives identified by communities working with
            NGOs/CBOs, and these projects will contribute to household
            food and nutrition security for the vulnerable individuals
            and foster households. The component will assist in the
            development of long-term capacity and provide technical
            assistance to NGOs/CBOs working directly with the vulnerable
            groups at the district, ward, and village levels. The third
            component, Community Savings and Investment Promotion
            (COMSIP) will, given the few formal opportunities for saving
            that exist, promote a savings and investment culture among
            the poor. Support under this component will not include the
            transfer of monies for savings or credit purposes, but will
            include promotion of COMSIGs of 10-15 members each. The
            fourth component, Transparency and Accountability Promotion,
            will develop suitable technical guidelines, generate data
            from the work of communities and partner institutions,
            process such data into useful information, disseminate, and
            package it into suitable materials for training. This
            component will also focus on developing an effective MIS
            which will feed into the overall monitoring and evaluation
            system. The fifth component, the Institutional Development
            component, will address the internal capacity requirements
            of MASAF to deliver in a transparent and accountable way. It
            will finance the continued provision of technically
            competent staff to work at the MASAF MU, and strengthen LA
            capacity to implement the community sub-project cycle with
            technical and financial expertise.

repnme.cdata!: Malawi - Third Social Action Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Environmental Assessment and
            Mitigation Framework under the Malawi social Action Fund
            (MASAF) seeks to institute a consistent and effective
            environmental assessment and mitigation mechanism for all
            MASAF activities at the community, district, and national
            levels. Specifically, the MASAF aims to 1) ensure that
            environmental assessments are undertaken at every project
            management sub-system level; and 2) support and empower
            communities to implement and monitor mitigation measures on
            MASAF-funded activities. This process will be routinely
            integrated within the sub-project cycle processes. Where
            needed, action plans to limit the negative effects arising
            from project activities will be instituted. Sectoral
            checklists will detail activities to be undertaken,
            potential negative impacts, and mitigation measures.
            Extension workers will elicit input from communities,
            including ongoing environmental monitoring once the project
            is approved. The Environmental District Officer will play a
            critical role in coordinating activities geared at
            supporting communities in environmental assessment. At the
            national level, the Environmental Affairs Department will
            insure that environmental assessment is carried out before
            funding is released for a particular activity. This
            department will also provide targeted messages designed to
            increase environmental awareness and promoting the use of
            alternative technologies, such as cement blocks, where
            appropriate. A workshop held in Salima in August 2002
            modified procedures and forms to be used specifically for
            use in the environmental assessment for the Third Social
            Action Fund; these are detailed in this report.

display_title.display_title:
Malawi - Third Social Action Fund
            Project : Environmental framework

The Environmental Assessment and
            Mitigation Framework under the Malawi social Action Fund
            (MASAF) seeks to institute a consistent and effective
            environmental assessment and mitigation mechanism for all
            MASAF activities at the community, district, and national
            levels. Specifically, the MASAF aims to 1) ensure that
            environmental assessments are undertaken at every project
            management sub-system level; and 2) support and empower
            communities to implement and monitor mitigation measures on
            MASAF-funded activities. This process will be routinely
            integrated within the sub-project cycle processes. Where
            needed, action plans to limit the negative effects arising
            from project activities will be instituted. Sectoral
            checklists will detail activities to be undertaken,
            potential negative impacts, and mitigation measures.
            Extension workers will elicit input from communities,
            including ongoing environmental monitoring once the project
            is approved. The Environmental District Officer will play a
            critical role in coordinating activities geared at
            supporting communities in environmental assessment. At the
            national level, the Environmental Affairs Department will
            insure that environmental assessment is carried out before
            funding is released for a particular activity. This
            department will also provide targeted messages designed to
            increase environmental awareness and promoting the use of
            alternative technologies, such as cement blocks, where

            modified procedures and forms to be used specifically for
